page.title: 13NATURAL HISTORY IN NE LEICS
page.content: The deciduous woodland and disused railway line, being seldom disturbed, provide ideal cover for most common British birds. Yellowhammers and linnets are abundant in the woodland, pigeon, lapwing, larks, and starlings on open ground.Yellow Wagtails as summer visitors breed successfully. Pheasant and partridge may also be seen. The woodland comprises mainly hawthorn ash and oak with blackberry, elderberry, wild rose and sloe bushes. Few elm trees have survived Dutch Elm disease. Many wild flowers are found such as cowslips, primrose, campion, willow herb and bluebells. Most of the common British mammals are found including badgers, foxes, hares, rabbits and hedgehogs. Badger setts and fox earths can be seen in the railway embankment.
